La socia desea invertir en la compra de animales menores al por mayor como gallinas doble pechugas  y engordarlas para la venta, otra parte del crédito desea invertirlo en la compra de maíz blanco para la nueva siembra y arroz, aceite al por mayor para su pensión restaurante.

La socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas.
texts.en:
Rocío, 30, is a member of the “Reyna de Los Angeles de Urquillos” communal bank located in Urquillos District in Calca Province and Cusco Department.

She’s married and has three children.  Her main activity is agriculture; she plants top grade white corn which is then taken to Urubamba in the Sacred Valley to be sold at wholesale.  She’s also a merchant.  She prepares home-cooked meals to sell.  She’s very well known in the town and is always visited to enjoy her delicious and diverse stews.  She also raises small farm animals like guinea pigs, chickens and pigs which, once fattened and mature, are taken to the markets to be sold at wholesale and retail.  

She would like to give her little children a better quality of life and this is why she works so much to be able to give them what they need and to save up for their education.

She wants to invest in the purchase of small farm animals at wholesale, like double breasted chickens, to fatten up to sell.  Another portion of the loan is to buy white corn for the new planting season and rice and oil at wholesale for her daily meal restaurant.

She is grateful for the support she’ll get and commits to make her installment payments in a disciplined manner.

loans.use: to invest in her various businesses.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.es:
Magdalena  es socia del  Banco Comunal “Virgen D. la Asunción”, ubicado en el distrito y provincia D. Yunguyo, departamento D. Puno, tiene 39 años D. edad, está casada y tiene 4 hijos.  Magdalena estudió la primaria.
Se dedica a la venta D. comidas en la plaza D. ganados, también tiene una tienda D. abarrotes, la que atienD. personalmente.  DesD. hace cinco años  trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos,  su primer  préstamo solicitado fue por la suma D.  S/ 300.00 nuevo soles, dinero que invirtió en su negocio.
Con éste nuevo préstamo D. S/ 1500.00 nuevo soles, comprará mercadería como arroz, azúcar, fideos, leche, aceite, huevo y otros insumos para seguir implementando su bodega.
Su sueño es tener buenos ganados, venderlos a buen precio para tener buena ganancia y solventar económicamente los estudios D. sus hijos.
Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal son las reuniones, la puntualidad y la responsabilidad.
texts.en:
Magdalena is a member of the “Virgen D. la Asunción” (Virgin of the Assumption) communal bank located in Yunguyo District and Province, Puno Department.  She’s 39 years old, married and has four children.  Magdalena went to elementary school.

She sells meals in the livestock exchange and she also has a grocery store that she tends to personally.  She’s been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for the last five years.  Her first loan request was for 300 new soles that she invested in her business.  She will use this new 1500 new sol loan to buy merchandise like rice, sugar, noodles, milk, oil, eggs and other ingredients to continue stocking her store.

Her dream is to have good livestock and sell it for good prices to have profits and meet her children’s educational expenses.  What she likes about the communal bank is the meetings, the punctuality and the responsibility.

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Evarista

texts.es: Evarista tiene  50 años, es natural de Huancavelica y tras haberse separado de su esposo, vive con sus tres hijos y por ellos trabaja con mucho ahínco. Motivada por las necesidades económicas que afrontaba aprendió a realizar bordados de manera artesanal sobre los trajes típicos muy utilizados en festividades locales llamada Santiago. Una de sus vecinas fue su maestra y tras 15 años de experiencia se ha convertido en una experta y cada trabajo que realiza tiene un buen acabado, considerándola como una de las mejores artesanas. Por ese prestigio goza de pedidos de sus clientes que se consideran fijos y siempre acuden a ella ya sea en vísperas de fiestas o eventos, muchos de ellos con nuevos clientes que recomiendan. Por lo que  para abastecerse en los pedidos también cuenta con el apoyo de su hija pero generalmente contrata mano de obra. En su taller cuenta con una maquina de coser que le sirve para dar los últimos acabados a las prendas elaboradas; los demás meses del año cuando  acaba esta festividad elabora mandiles típicos que siempre son muy solicitados. Evarista siente gran satisfacción de su trabajo porque le permite desarrollarla en su misma casa y disponer de su tiempo. Mas adelante desea incrementar su producción en fustanes bordados como también de mandiles. Este es su tercer crédito que tiene con MFP de manera grupal  que le ha permitido mejorar su actividad económica, siempre ha demostrado su responsabilidad en sus pagos porque siempre ha invertido netamente en su negocio. Ahora con el dinero que solicita,  lo invertirá en la compra de telas e hilos de colores.
texts.en:
Evarista is 50 years old.  She is from Huancavelica and after separating from her husband lives with her three children for whom she works with much dedication.  Motivated by the economic need she faced she learned to do artisanal embroidery on traditional costumes used in the local festival called Santiago.  One of her neighbors was her teacher and after 15 years of experience she has become an expert and each job she does is well finished; she’s considered to be one of the best artisans.  

Because of that prestige, she is favored by orders from customers that consider themselves to be regular and always come to her on the eve of festivals or events many of them with new customers to recommend.  To fill her orders she calls on her daughter for help but generally hires hands to help her.  She has a sewing machine in her shop that she uses to apply the finishing touches to the items she makes.  During the rest of the year after the festival is over she makes traditional aprons that are always in demand.

Evarista is very satisfied with her work because she’s able to carry it out in her home and she can manage her own time.  Later on she’d like to increase production of embroidered petticoats as well as aprons.

This is her third group loan with MFP that has helped her improve her economic activity.  She’s always been responsible with her payments because she’s always invested in her business.  Now, with the requested money, she’ll buy fabric and thread in assorted colors.

loans.use: to buy fabric and thread in assorted colors.

loans.name: Mauricia

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “MAMA SIMONA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco,  y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Mauricia; ella tiene 43 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 3 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de golosinas, ella vende chupetes,caramelos,chicles entre otras golosinas, la socia también se dedica al negocio de venta de comida los días sábados y domingos en forma ambulatoria y la venta de golosinas lo realiza en el distrito de Poroy que queda a unos 20 minutos de la ciudad de Cusco, la socia quiere ampliar el negocio de venta de golosinas y negocio de venta de comida. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar golosinas y productos para cocinar como carne, arroz y verduras.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              
 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
This member is part of the “Mama Simona” communal bank, located in the Cusco district of the Cusco province and department.

Mauricia is 43 years old, is in a live in relationship, and has three children.  She sells snacks, lollypops, caramels, and gum among other things, in the Poroy district, about 20 minutes from the City of Cusco.  She also sells food on foot on the weekends.  [Mauricia] wants to expand her snack and food business and is asking for this loan to buy snacks and ingredients such as meat, rice, and vegetables.

She is happy about the loan and is committed to making her payments on schedule.

loans.use: to buy snacks and ingredients

loans.name: Los Poetas Group

texts.es:
Este banco comunal se llama “Los Poetas” está conformado por 18 emprendedores que se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre estos transportador de frutas y verduras, peluquería, venta de artículos de baño, venta de ropa, administración de máquinas tragamonedas. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la ciudad de Temuco. 
Macarena quien en la foto se encuentra de pie en la priM. fila, en el lugar del medio, viste una chaqueta color beige, su cabello es oscuro y usa chasquilla. Se dedica a vender abarrotes, bebidas y lácteos en un almacén. Trabaja en éste rubro desde hace 6 meses y su negocio está ubicado en un local que arrienda. Comenta que le ha ido muy bien desde que inició su negocio. 
Con el crédito comprará mercadería para surtir su negocio. Sus metas son surgir en su negocio, que le pueda brindar mayores ganancias para seguir invirtiendo y concretar sus sueños personales.
Macarena vive junto a sus abuelos y un tío. Sus sueños son obtener su casa propia, para esto postuló al subsidio habitacional. 
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida del crédito otorgado por Fondo Esperanza. Participa activamente de las reuniones, ya que es presidenta del banco comunal al cual pertenece, tiene una muy buena relación con las demás socias del grupo, incluso las apoya a participar de las actividades realizadas. 
Temuco es la capital de la región de la Araucanía. La ciudad se ubica a 670 kilómetros al sur de Santiago (capital de Chile). En sus alrededores se ubican una serie de balnearios lacustres (Pucón, Villarrica) y una flora y fauna nativa muy llamativas, concentrada en parques naturales cercanos. Cabe destacar que en esta región habita el 50% de los mapuches, pueblo indígena, existente en nuestro país.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Los Postes” and is made up of 18 entrepreneurs who work in different fields, such as transporting fruits and vegetables, barber, toiletries sales, clothing sales, and slot machine management.  All of them live in the city of Temuco.

Macarena, shown with dark hair, a beige jacket, and jewelry in the photograph and who is standing in the middle of the first row, sells groceries, drinks, and milk products in a small store.  She’s been working in this line of business for six months and does it from a rented location.  She tells us that things have gone well since she began her business.

She will use the money from this loan to buy merchandise to stock her store.  Her goals are to continue with her business so that she can increase her income and invest in her own dreams.

Macarena lives with her grandparents and uncle.  She hopes to get her own home, so she applied to the housing authority.

She is very happy and grateful about the loan granted through Fondo Esperanza.  She is an active participant in the meetings and is president of the communal bank to which she belongs.  She has a good relationship with the other members of the group and supports them in their activities.

Temuco is the capitol of the Araucanía region, and the city is located 670 km south of Santiago (capitol of Chile).  It is surrounded by lake spas (Pucón, Villarrica) and some very attractive flora and fauna in the nearby parks.  50% of the Mapuche indigenous people, native to the country, live in this region.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to stock her store

loans.name: Los Encinos Group

texts.es: La señora Maria es originaria de una localidad llamada La Barranca un lugar hermosos con unos espectaculares paisajes, ella es parte del grupo El Encinal y comenta que le pusieron ese nombre al grupo por que donde hacen sus reuniones hay muchos árboles de ese árbol llamado encino y es por eso que le pusieron ese nombre. Doña Maria tiene 5 hijos hace poco ella enviudo y ahora esta a cargo de sus pequeños hijos, comenta María que ella se dedica a la cría y venta de borregos y al cultivo de aguacate desde hace 8 años que su esposo y ella decidieron emprender ese negocio para sacar adelante a sus hijos y darles una carrera. Ella esta pidiendo un crédito a la financiera para comprar borregos pequeños y ponerlos en engorda y después venderlos en su localidad. También ella se dedica a la venta de aguacate comenta que en temporada de lluvias es cuando mas se le vende y lo puede dar a mejor precio, comenta que de esas ganancias que obtenga ella ahorrara para cómprales a sus pequeños hijos los útiles escolares ya que pronto entraran a un nuevo ciclo escolar. La meta que tiene la señora Maria es salir adelante con sus hijos y hacer una tienda de abarrotes en su casa para estar mas al pendiente de sus niños.
texts.en:
Maria is originally from an area called La Barranca, a beautiful place with spectacular landscapes.  She’s part of a group called El Encinal and she tells us that the members decided to name it that way because there are many oak trees (Encino in Spanish) in the place when they hold their meetings.  Maria has five children and was recently widowed.  She raises sheep and grows avocados and she and her husband had been doing this together for eight years.  They decided to start this business so that they could help their children get ahead and be able to establish careers.

She is asking for this loan in order to buy lambs to raise and sell in her area.  She also sells avocadoes and tells us that she gets the best prices during the rainy season.  It’s from those earnings that she saves up to buy her children’s school supplies, especially now that they are getting ready to begin a new school year.

Maria’s goal is to get ahead with her children and open a small grocery store in her home, so that she can better care for her children.

loans.use: to buy lambs to raise

loans.name: Felix Antonio

texts.es: Félix hombre trabajador casado, su esposa comerciante, sus hijos ya independiente le ayudan a sus padres. Proyecto mejorar la infraestructura de su vivienda. Tiene su propio negocio ya que es de profesión albañil desde hace tiempo trabajando por temporada proyectos, pero también trabaja por cuenta propia.  El préstamo lo requiere para la compra de materiales de construcción como: cemento, arena, piedrines, bloques, piedras cantera, hierro, tablones de maderas, entre otros materiales para construir un muro de la propiedad. Obtenida protección, seguridad para sus seres queridos.
texts.en: Félix is a hard working married man.  His wife is a merchant and his children, already on their own, help their parents.  He wants to improve the infrastructure of his home.  He has his own business and works as a mason, both on formal projects and on his own.  He will use the money from this loan to buy building materials such as cement, sand, stone, cinder blocks, quarry stone, iron bars, plywood sheets, among other things that he will use to build a wall around his property.  This will provide security for his loved ones.

loans.use: to buy building materials

loans.name: Lucila

texts.es:
Lucila  es socia del  Banco Comunal “Virgen D. la Asunción”, ubicado en el distrito y provincia D. Yunguyo, departamento D. Puno, tiene 45 años D. edad, está  casada y tiene 3 hijos, dos D. ellos ya independientes.  Lucila estudió hasta 3ro D. secundaria.
Trabaja desD. hace cuatro años con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos, su primer préstamo solicitado fue D. S/. 500.00 nuevo soles, préstamo que invirtió en su negocio D. venta al por mayor D. granos.
Actualmente se dedica a la venta D. prendas D. vestir.  Con éste nuevo préstamo D. S/ 2500.00 nuevo soles, comprará 150 casacas D. todas las tallas.  Nos cuenta que compra sus productos en Desaguadero y los venD.  en el mercado D. Yunguyo y Juliaca.  Su esposo se encarga D. venderlas en la ciudad D. Lima.
Su sueño es mejorar el negocio, aumentar más su mercadería y así obtener más ingresos económicos, con ello podrá comprar su casa.
Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal es la facilidad del préstamo y la ganancia del ahorro.
texts.en:
Lucilia is a member of the “Virgen D. la Asunción” communal bank, located in the district and province of Yunguyo, in the Puno department.  She is 45 years old, married, and has three children, two of whom are on their own.  She has a 9th graD. education.

Lucilia has been working with “Movimiento Manuela Ramos” for four years and her first loan was for 500 PEN, which she used to invest into her business of selling bulk grain.  Now she sells clothing and she will use the money from this 2,500 PEN ($925) loan to buy 150 coats of various sizes.  She tells us that she buys her products in Desaguadero and sells them in the “Yunguyo y Juliaca” market in Lima.

Her greatest dream is to improve her business, increase her inventory of merchandise, and in this way increase her income so that she can buy a house.  What she likes most about the communal bank in the ease of obtaining loans and the savings.

loans.use: to buy coats for resale

loans.name: Primitiva

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “MAMA SIMONA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco,  y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Primitiva; ella tiene 45 años de edad y es viuda y tiene 4 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de leña y venta de chicha que es una bebida a base de maíz, la socia trabaja en forma independiente, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m,por medio de estos pequeños negocios la socia saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio de venta de leña y venta de chicha. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar leña al por mayor y para comprar insumos para preparar la chicha como maíz y jora.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en: This borrower belong to the "Mama Simona" communal bank, which is located in the district, province, and department of Cusco. This borrower is Ms. Primitiva. She is a 45 year-old widow and has four children. She divides her time between her daily activities and her businesses selling firewood and chica, which is a corn-based beverage. She works independently, from 8:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m. Through these small businesses, Primitiva has helped her children to get ahead. She would like to expand and improve her businesses of selling firewood and chicha. She is requesting a loan to buy firewood wholesale and to buy ingredients for preparing chicha, such as corn and jora [germinated, dried corn kernels]. Primitiva is happy to receive this loan and promises to comply with her repayment schedule.

loans.use: to buy firewood wholesale and to buy ingredients for preparing traditional Peruvian corn beer

loans.name: El Esfuerzo Group

texts.es:
Este banco comunal se llama “El Esfuerzo” está conformado por 20 emprendedores que se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre estos se encuentran venta de confites, corte y confección, además de locales de comida rápida. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la ciudad de Valdivia.
Griselda quien en la foto se encuentra de pie en el medio del grupo, vistiendo una chaqueta color negro y una bufanda color rosado. Se dedica a la confitería desde hace 4 años, vendiendo confites, galletas, papas fritas, entre otros. Su negocio lo traslada en un triciclo y se ubica afuera de consultorios, colegios y ferias. Su horario es relativo, ya que durante la semana trabaja de 8ºº de la mañana hasta las 03ºº de la tarde y el día domingo durante la mañana, que es cuando vende en la feria libre. 
Su mercadería la compra en una distribuidora en la ciudad de Osorno.
Con el crédito comprará mercadería para surtir su negocio de confitería.
Sus metas son surtir su negocio, principalmente durante la temporada de verano para vender helados, ya que con esto pretende generar mayores ingresos para arrendar un kiosco y así tener un negocio más estable. 
Griselda vive junto a su esposo e hijo de 6 años de edad. Uno de sus sueños es acceder a su vivienda propia para esto postuló al subsidio habitacional. Otro de sus anhelos es que su hija sea una profesional. 
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida del crédito obtenido por Fondo Esperanza, ya que le ha servido para invertir en su negocio y con esto la posibilidad de generar mayores ganancias. 
Además durante las reuniones del banco comunal, ha podido conocer a los demás socios.
Valdivia es una ciudad del sur de Chile, ubicada en la región de Los Ríos. Se destaca por tener uno de los pocos ríos navegables de Chile, el Calle Calle. Valdivia presenta, dentro de sus principales actividades económicas, la industria de la construcción naval, maderera, papelera, celulosa (Celco), cervecera y molinera. El turismo desempeña un papel importante, como también los servicios educacionales universitarios, encabezados por la Universidad Austral de Chile.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called "El Esfuerzo" (Effort). It is made up of 20 entrepreneurs who work in different fields, including candy sales, tailoring, and fast food. They are all from Valdivia city.

Griselda, who in the photo is standing in the middle of the group, wearing a black jacket and pink scarf, has worked as a confectioner for four years, selling candy, cookies, chips, and other items. She sells her goods from a  tricycle, stopping outside clinics, schools and fairs. Her timetable is flexible, as during the week she works from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. and on Sunday morning she sells her goods at the open market.
She buys her merchandise from a distributor in Osorno city.

With the loan, she will buy merchandise to stock up her confectionery business.
Her goal is to stock up her business, especially so that she can sell ice cream during the summer, as this will allow her to generate more income and thus rent a kiosk and have a more stable business.

Griselda lives with her husband and six-year-old child. One of her dreams is to have her own house, and for this she has applied for a the housing subsidy. Another of his wishes is that her child should have a  professional career.

She is very happy and grateful for the loan obtained through Kiva Field Partner, Fondo Esperanza, as it has allowed her to invest in her business with the possibility of generating higher profits.
Also, during the communal bank meetings, she has been able to meet the other members.

Valdivia is a city in southern Chile, located in the Los Rios region. It is known for having one of the few navigable rivers in Chile, the Calle-Calle. Valdivia has, among its main economic activities, a shipbuilding industry, a timber industry, a paper mill, a pulp mill (Celco), a brewery and mills. Tourism plays an important role, as well as educational services, led by the Universidad Austral de Chile.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to stock up her confectionery business.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia is 36 years old and married with two children. Her children are 10 and 14 years old. She is the owner of a bread store where she sells all different types of breads. Some of her specialties are French bread, pastries with dulce de leche, and sweet bread. Virginia works every day of the week making and selling bread. With a 1,200 USD loan, Virginia plans to purchase more flour, sugar, and butter to make bread for her store. She hopes eventually that she will be able to make a greater quantity of bread so that she can buy her own ovens, as she currently rents them. Virginia is very hardworking and committed to making all of the loan payments on time.

loans.use: to buy more flour, sugar, and butter to make bread

loans.name: Jaime Ignacio

texts.en: Jaime Ignacio is 48 years old and married with four children. His children are 13, 14, 19, and 22. For the past 4 years Jaime has had his own ceviche stand. (Ceviche is a dish composed of raw fish soaked in lime juice, salt, and onions.) Jaime has a small stand in a local market but is hoping to upgrade to his own restaurant soon. With a 1,200 USD loan, Jaime will begin to expand his small stand by purchasing more supplies for his kitchen in order to make more ceviche to sell. He is committed to making all the loan payments on time.

loans.use: to buy more supplies to make ceviche

loans.name: Wendell

texts.en: Wendell is 60 years old and married with 6 children. His occupation is a taxi driver in the city of Cusco. Wendell has been in this line of work for about 8 years and works every single day. He plans to put his 200 USD loan towards purchasing his own taxi because he currently rents the taxi that he drives every day. It is his dream to have his own car and therefore be an independent taxi driver. Wendell is committed to making the loan payments on time.

loans.use: to purchase his own taxi

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is 28 years old and married with one child who is 8 months old. Nine months ago, Stella opened a small cafe in which she sells coffee, tea, and various pastries. In addition, she sells beauty products to a number of different clients. The items include hair products, perfumes, and facial cleansing products. With a 900 USD loan, Stella plans to purchase the latest beauty supplies so that her clients can receive the best possible products. She is a very hardworking woman and is committed to making all of the loan payments on time.

loans.use: to buy the latest beauty products to sell to her clients

loans.name: Braulio

texts.en: Braulio is 39 years old and married with two children. His children are 10 and 14 years old. Braulio works as a taxi driver in the city of Cusco. He enjoys his occupation and works everyday. With an 800 USD loan, Braulio plans to invest in his wife's bakery. A large portion of the loan will go to purchasing ingredients for bread, while the rest will be for minor improvements to her store. Braulio and his wife are committed to making all of the necessary loan payments on time.

loans.use: to invest in his wife's bakery

loans.name: Justino

texts.en:
Justino is 60 years old and married with two children. 

He is the owner and operator of a sauna. His sauna is very popular and many people go there to relax and treat themselves to a wonderful day. 

Justino is asking for a $1,200 loan to improve his sauna and he wishes to make repairs to aspects of the sauna that are worn out. 

He is a very responsible man and is committed to making all of the necessary loan payments on time.

loans.use: to pay for repairs to his sauna.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mrs. Keo, 43, is humble villager in the Ornlong Veng district and the mother of four children, one of which is married and three of whom are single. Most of the children are employed as internal staff in local hotels and they always share their low incomes with Mrs. Keo so that she can use it for the family expenses. Mrs. Keo and her husband are local farmers who have been planting a variety of crops for a few years. Aside from this farming, she often distills liquor at home in order to make alcohol to sell for extra-income. Mrs. Keo will use part of the loan to mend her plowing machine so that she can use it to plow on her fertile land, and she will use the other part of loan fund to buy fertilizers and seed for planting.

loans.use: to mend her plowing machine, and purchase fertilizers and seed for planting.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for her children to drive to their school location.

loans.name: Dou

texts.en: Mrs. Dou is 32 years old and a married woman who lives in the Kompong Speu Province. She is a local cultivator, sells bees for extra-income, and she has three children, all of whom are attending school and living under her income. She currently generates an income of approximately $5 per day. To help support her in paying the financial expenses, her husband provides a motor taxi service to his villagers and other travelers. Typically, Mrs. Dou hires her neighbor’s cow to plow her farmland. To help reduce her costs, Mrs. Dou is applying for a loan to purchase a cow. She will use some part of a loan to build a new bathroom for her family to use.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and build a new bathroom for her family to use.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is 46 years old and married with seven children.

Monica works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks to sell in her store.

Monica has borrowed and paid 11 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 3 years and also earns an income from farming vegetables.

Monica aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks to sell in her store.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is 33 years old and married.

Geraldine works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like soft-drinks, bread, eggs, etc in her sari-sari store.

Geraldine has borrowed and paid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 3 years and also earns an income from farming rice.

Geraldine aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell.

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase fishing nets and other materials for her fishing business.

Glenda has been in this business for 20 years. Glenda earns more income from dried fish vending.

Glenda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and other materials

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 40 years old and married with two children.

She earns a living by growing vegetables in the Philippines. Gloria is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Gloria has been growing vegetables for three years and earns additional income from growing rice.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy additional fish to sell for her fish vending business.

Gloria has been in this business for 15 years. Gloria earns more income from fishing and raising pigs.

Gloria has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional fish to sell

loans.name: Bienvenido

texts.en:
Bienvenido is 59 years old and is married. He has nine children. 

 Bienvenido grows rice and has been doing it for 30 years. He is thankful because his business is doing well. He earns about PHP 10,000 monthly.

Bienvenido would like to improve his rice farm to make it more productive. To fulfill this dream, he is asking for a loan of PHP 50,000 to use as additional capital in purchasing fertilizer and some insecticides needed at his farm.

In the future, Bienvenido hopes that his rice farming business will improve through wise maintenance and the provision of every need of the farm.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and some insecticides needed in his farm.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 43 years old and married with five children.

Josephine works hard to provide for her family. She runs a General Store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her general store.

Josephine has borrowed and paid 4 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the General Store for 2 years and also earns an income from farming rice.

Josephine aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Neang, 50 year old, is married. Her husband is a chief of construction workers. Their income is $8 per day. They have four children. Three are studying and one is working as a teacher in state school with $3 per day for his income. 

Every month, she has to spend $75 on food, $50 on school fees, $30 on transportation and $35 on other expenses.

Neang feeds and sells animals. Her career can make good profits, so she wants to buy more pigs to feed whenever she can save enough money to buy them. She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy pigs and chickens to feed and sell. 

For her children, she wants to send them to study at the university when they finish high school.

loans.use: To buy pigs and chickens to feed and sell.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 29500 through NWTF to purchase more fish to sell for her fish vending business.

Imelda has been in this business for 20 years. Imelda earns more income from raising pigs.

Imelda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Chheuen

texts.en:
Chheuen, 33 year old, is scavenger. His wife is working in the factory and their income is $5 per day. He has three children, and one of them is studying. 

Every month, he has to spend $40 on food, $5 on electricity, $10 on rent, $10 on school fees, $15 on transportation and $20 on other expenses. 

He notices that his business can make a good profit, so he plans to extend his business by purchasing more recyclable items to stock whenever he is able to save enough money.

He would like to request a loan of $800 to buy items to recycle and resell. He hopes to send all of his children to study in the university when they finish high school.

loans.use: To buy items to recycle and resell

loans.name: Soknoy

texts.en:
Soknoy is a silk weaver. Her husband is a hair cutter. Their income is $5 per day. She has three children. Two are studying. 

Every month, she has to spend $40 on food, $20 on transportation, $10 on school fees and $20 on other expenses. 

She would like to request a loan of $600 to buy silk to weave and sell. 

She plans to repair her house when she can save enough money. For her children, she will try to send them to study until they finish university.

loans.use: To buy raw silk to weave and sell.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en: Lourdes is in the agricultural business farming vegetables in the Philippines. She is 45 years old and has four children. Lourdes is married and one of her children is in school. Lourdes has been farming vegetables for three years now and has borrowed five times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business. Lourdes requested a 14,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies. In the future, Lourdes would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her child to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Sot

texts.en: Mrs. Sot is a 23 year-old woman who has been living in Kompong Speu Province. She has worked for a local organization as an internal staff and she receives a formal salary monthly. She is married to Mr. Moul, 38, who is employed as a policeman in his community, and he also receives a formal salary every month. Mr. Moul always shares his responsibility with Mrs. Sot and uses his income to help pay the whole family’s expenses. Beside her job, Mrs. Sot has raised a lot of chickens and she had hopes to sell them to buyers three or four months after she begins raising them. Unfortunately, the chickens are not big enough, due to the lack of food. To help solve this problem, Mrs. Sot has requested a loan of $300 that she will use to buy many sacks of chickens feed to fatten her chickens.

loans.use: to buy many sacks of chickens feed to fatten her chickens.

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Chanthy, a mother of three children aged four, two and one, is a weaver and raises animals at home, while her husband performs cremation services. They earn a combined daily income of $11. Every month they spend $83 on food, $50 on transportation, $10 on electricity and $60 on other expenses.

Chanthy is now requesting a loan of $1200 to buy a motorbike for her husband to use while traveling to cremate the deceased. In the future, she wants to buy a truck to transport the bodies for cremation so that her husband can earn more income. Chanthy also aspires to support their children's education until they finish university.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband's business travel.

loans.name: Emelinda

texts.en: Emelinda is 54 years old and a widow with five children. She is in the agricultural business farming vegetables in the Philippines. She has been farming vegetables for three years now and has borrowed five times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business. Emelinda requested a 14,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies. Emelinda would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is married with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Jennifer is 38 years old and has one child who is in school.

Jennifer has a tricycle transport business in the Philippines. Jennifer requested a PHP 11,000 loan from NWTF to buy spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

Jennifer has been in this business for nine years. In the future, Jennifer would like to save enough to provide financial stability for her family.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to maintain her motorcycle

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fruits and vegetables vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 19,000 through NWTF to purchase additional fruits and vegetables to sell for her fruits and vegetables vending business.

Jessie has been in this business for eight years. Jessie earns more income from a general store.

Jessie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additonal fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Run

texts.en:
Run, a single mother with two children, lives with one of her sisters and her mother. As a vegetable planter, Run can earn a daily income of about $6.6, while her sister, a garment factory worker, makes $3 per day. Every month, she has to spend $83 on food, $10 on school fees, $5 on electricity, $50 on transportation, and $40 on other expenses.

Run is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy clothes for her sister to sell in the factory where she works. She could earn a good income with this business and plans to get a small shop to sell clothes when she has enough money.

loans.use: to buy clothes for her sister to sell in the factory.

loans.name: Apolonia

texts.en:
Apolonia works hard to support her family. Apolonia is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Apolonia requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to purchase fishing gear and equipment.

Apolonia has been in this business for 20 years now and earns additional income from fish vending.

Apolonia would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase fishing gear and equipment.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a welding shop business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 23,000 through NWTF to buy additional materials and equipment for her welding shop.

Jocelyn has been in this business for 13 years. Jocelyn earns more income from tricycle transport.

Jocelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional materials and equipment for her shop

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Kate is 50 years old and has two children.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Kate is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Kate has been farming rice for 10 years and earns additional income from food vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Jumpu

texts.en:
Jumpu, is waitress in a restaurant. Her husband rents a small shop, near his house, to sell phones. Their income is $15 per day. 

Every month, Jumpu spends $30 on food, $5 electricity, $10 on house rent fees and $5 on transportation. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy new and second hand phones to resell. This loan will lead her husband to be able to have some money to continue his business and he can buy more phones and other items related to selling phones. In the future, this family plan to have their own shop to sell from so that they don’t have to pay to rent a house.

loans.use: to buy new and second hand phones to resell.

loans.name: Vouen

texts.en: Vouen is factory worker. Her income is $3.50 per day. She lives with her mother and three siblings. They work in a factory with an income of $3 per day for each of them. Every month she spends $75 on food, $10 on electricity, $30 on housing rental, $40 on transportation and $50 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1200 to buy a motorbike for traveling to work in the factory. The family expenses are not solely her responsibility alone, the siblings also help because they have an old mother living with them. When she is able to save enough money, Vouen plans to buy chickens and pigs for her mother to raise at home.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for traveling to her factory job.

loans.name: Suong

texts.en:
Mrs. Suong has been spending her life cultivating crops in the Kompong Speu Province. This is a skill she learned from her grandparent when she was young. She is now married and has three kids. Her husband works in the garment factory and has a fixed salary each month. Mrs. Suong’s husband faces difficulties with his traveling needs because he always pays a lot of money to a taxi driver when he wants to go to his work place and other places. Therefore, Mrs. Suong hopes to reduce the amount her husband spends on transportation by using her loan to purchase a motorbike. 

Note: Mrs. Suong and her husband are shown in the photo.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fruit vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of fruit to sell for her fruit vending business.

Leah has been in this business for two years. Leah earns more income from food vending.

Leah has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional fruits to sell

loans.name: Diego

texts.en:
Diego is 35 years old and married to Imelda, who manages their general store. The couple is blessed with 2 children and they are school-aged. According to Diego, he is able to earn about PHP 50,000 per cropping harvest. The rice farming business is not the only source of income of the family instead they also managed a retail shop within the village where they live.

Diego grows rice and has been doing it for almost 15 years. He would like to make his farm more productive, that's why he is asking for a loan of PHP 50,000 as his additional capital in maintaining and improving his farm. 

In the future, Diego hopes that he can avail his loan request so that he can provide the farm supplies needed in the maintenance of his rice farm. He also wants to increase his income to be able to provide for the needs of his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticides for his farm.

loans.name: Yut

texts.en: From the Baray District of Kompong Tom Province, Mrs. Yut, age 50, owns and operates a small kiosk shop located inside a secondary school where she sells various cakes to the students. She normally makes US $3 in profit each day to support the family's daily expense. A few sources of family income come from her husband who is a professional teacher. Aside her selling business, Mrs. Yut has been planting a rice crop as an annual activity. Mrs. Yut will use the loan that she is borrowing to purchase fertilizers and seeds for farming. She has five children, one of whom works at a local organization while the other four are still learning in public school. She hopes to use the rest of the fund to pay for school fees for her children in the new semester.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds and to pay for school fees for her kids.

loans.name: Evelia

texts.en:
Evelia is 58 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 4 children. 

Evelia has a shop where she sells snacks, beverages & canned goods. She has had this business for 6 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 11,000 to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks.

Evelia has been a member of HSPFI since 2005. In the future, Evelia hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is 72 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed and has 4 children. 

Yolanda has a shop where she sells snacks, breads & biscuits. She has had this business for 36 years. She requested a loan for PHP 9,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Yolanda has been a member of HSPFI since 2006. In the future, Yolanda hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia is 49 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with six children. 

Emelia has a shop that sells coconut wine by the gallon. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 6,000 to buy plastic containers for the coconut wine.

Emelia has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Emelia hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy plastic containers for coconut wine

loans.name: Leonisa

texts.en:
Leonisa is 49 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with seven children. 

Leonisa has a shop that sells canned goods, biscuits & snacks. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, detergents & bread.

Leonisa has been a member of HSPFI since 2007. In the future, Leonisa hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, detergents & bread

loans.name: Rhory

texts.en:
Rhory is 28 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with two children. 

Rhory has a shop that sells frozen foods like dressed chickens & hot dogs. He has had this business for five years. He requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy additional stocks of frozen foods like dressed chickens.

Rhory is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Rhory hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy additional frozen foods like dressed chickens

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 36 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with five children. 

Richard peddles cooked peanuts in different flavors. He has had this business for five years. He requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy additional peanuts to sell.

Richard is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Richard hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy additional peanuts to sell

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is 62 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with six children. 

Lolita has a shop that sells snacks, bread & beverages. She has had this business for 15 years. She requested a loan of PHP 4,000 to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks.

Lolita has been a member of HSPFI since 2006. In the future, Lolita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her children.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy an additional stock of coconut shells

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store

loans.name: Esperansa

texts.en:
This is Esperansa, 47, a resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Ediegario, a vendor, and mother to their child. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Esperansa operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Esperansa earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Esperansa hopes to be able to expand soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store

loans.name: Wilbert

texts.en:
Wilbert is 30 and married to Amilyn. The couple is blessed with two children. Wilbert is thankful because his wife helps him provide for the needs of their children. His wife is engaged in vending shoes and Wilbert is managing their rice farming business. Wilbert is able to earn about PHP 30,000 per cropping.

Wilbert grows rice. He has been doing this for 10 years. He would like to improve his farm by inputting all the farm supplies needed, but due to a shortage of funds he needs the assistance of the lenders. He is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 as his additional capital to buy farm supplies such as fertilizer, insecticides and seeds to grow.

In the future, Wilbert hopes that he can produce more crops and harvest more cavans of rice, so that he can sustain all the needs of his family, especially his children who are studying.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, insecticides and seeds

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
This is Jocelyn, 35, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Millirocen, an overseas Filipino worker and a painter.  She has three children, one of whom is not yet of school age and two who are in school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. Like most Filipino parents, Jocelyn believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children. 

Jocelyn operates a silkscreen printing business. Silkscreen printing is the process of creating a stencil in a mesh screen, then using a squeegee to push the inks through the mesh onto the shirt or garment. Clients go to Jocelyn to request printing; they provide their desired pattern or design. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. Jocelyn earns a minimum of PHP 9500 per month from her work.    

To help her continue the operation of her business, Jocelyn is requesting a loan of PHP 13,000. She will use the loan to buy more raw materials, like paint, screen, and shirts. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Jocelyn dreams of being able to give her children a high-quality education through all her hard work at her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw materials and items needed in her business.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is 42 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed with 4 children. 

Veronica has a butcher shop that sells pork and beef. She has had this business for 11 years. She has requested a loan of PHP 9,000 to buy additional stock of beef and pork to sell.

Veronica has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. Veronica hopes to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional stock of beef and pork to sell.

loans.name: Charya

texts.en:
Charya (pictured above) is a weaver, while her husband is a driver for a company. The couple has been married since 2008 and has one young son. They live on an island located fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Charya is applying for a loan of $500 to assist her brother, who is a teacher, in buying a motorbike for transportation to his teaching job.

loans.use: To assist her brother, who is a teacher, in buying a motorbike to for transportation to work.

loans.name: Rose Jean

texts.en:
This is Rosejean, 34, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Zacarias, a driver, and mother to her child. By the grace of God, Rosejean has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to send her daughter to school to finish her degree.

Rosejean oversees operations of their jeepney (see footnote) transportation business. They have a jeepney that has a capacity of 18 persons, which is paying a boundary (daily quota) of 1,000 each day. Rosejean’s husband drives the jeepney. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will use he loan to buy new tires for the jeepneys, and renew her registration. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Rosejean dreams that her child will finish her education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

-Curiously, Jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for every day travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly Philippines.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for new parts, accessories and registration of her vehicle

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
This is Nenita, 31, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to July Tito, a driver, and she is a mother of two children. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. Like most Filipino parents, Nenita believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Nenita operates an internet café business. There is more need, now than before, for services like these as customers’ demand increases. Her main patrons are students, who require her services for school requirements. She also has people who need to rent computers for business purposes like writing a resume or any office documentation, as well as people who just love to surf the net and social networks. Aside from the internet café, Nenita is into direct selling. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 619 in profit every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 29,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy an additional computer, mouse, keyboard, mouse pad, and other supplies for her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Nenita dreams of giving her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for computer parts and accessories

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric is 24 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is single. 

Eric is providing motorela or habal-habal services. He has had this business for three years. He requested a loan for PHP 9,000 to buy tools & pay for the utilities needed for the service.

Eric has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Eric hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools & pay for utilities

loans.name: Brang

texts.en:
Brang, 32 years old, is a housewife. Her husband is a motorbike repairer. She has 2 children, 11 and 2 years old, one of whom attends school. Every month, Brang spends around $50 on all the family's expenses.

Brang would like to request a loan of $500 to buy a plot of land to pump the sand to sell. Her husband has been doing motorbike repair for about ten years and now he wants to get another career (pumping the sand) so that he can earn more income because he is the only one earning money to support the family.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land to pump the sand to sell

loans.name: Lyda

texts.en:
Lyda (pictured with her loom) is a silk weaver. Her husband, Vuth, is in the army, working at the Air Force Headquarters base in Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1993 and have three children - one son and two daughters. All of them are in school.  

Lida has previously asked for a Kiva loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work. She now is asking for another loan of $1,200 to purchase one more motorbike for her children to drive to school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to school.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
This is Rebecca, 53, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Carlo, an operator, and has two children, who are already working and settled down with their own families. Rebecca and her husband manage their own household while operating their business. At this time, Rebecca is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Rebecca operates a variety store which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5 worth of cooking oil or an egg. Rebecca earns a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. In addition to her variety store, Rebecca oversees operations of their jeepney transportation business – a type of public transportation in the Philippines. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. Rebecca earns a minimum of PHP 1,680 every day.

To help her continue her business operations, Rebecca is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Rebecca hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes her grandchild to finish schooling. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
This is Lourdes, 51, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Rodrigo, who assists her in the business. Lourdes, her husband and their children manage their own household while operating their business. At this time, Lourdes is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Lourdes operates a variety store which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5 worth of cooking oil or an egg. Lourdes earns a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also earns additional income through her catering business, cooking for people in her neighborhood for special occasions. Lourdes' store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 1,131 in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, Lourdes is requesting a PHP 28,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Lourdes hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to establish her catering business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and other items needed in her business.

loans.name: Sampang

texts.en: Sampang, 27 years old, is a tuk tuk (auto rickshaw) driver. His wife sells food and their combined income is $10 per day. They have a 1-year-old child. Every month, Sampang spends $50 on food, $30 on transportation and $10 on other expenses. He would like to request a loan of $1,000 to buy a new motorbike to replace his current one because it is old and needs a lot of fixing. He plans to use the rest of the money to buy wood to repair his house. When he has enough money in the future, Sampang wants to get a small place for his wife to sell food.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
This is Gemma, 45, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Vicente, a vendor, and mother of seven children. One of the children is already employed. Three have already finished their studies, and the rest are still studying. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Gemma operates a food processing business. She has a factory a few steps from her house where they manufacture meat products. Gemma earns an income by selling her goods to her neighbors and to suppliers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 466 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 16,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy additional processed and frozen meat products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Gemma hopes to be able to expand soon, as she dreams of giving her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work ion her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for frozen meat products .

loans.name: Man

texts.en:
Man sells recycling materials. His wife, Satas, now stays at home and does housework. They live along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Man is asking for a loan of $200 to build a concrete brick room under his house.

Photo: Man is not sitting at his home. He is at his brother’s home.

loans.use: To build a concrete brick room under his house.

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Mrs. Yim would like to open a wedding salon to prepare brides and grooms for their wedding and wedding photographs. She will perform hair styling, makeup application and help them prepare their outfits. Preparing for the wedding and photographs is very important in Khmer culture. She has been doing these activities informally for some time but would like to open a shop so that she can serve more clients. This is the reason she is requesting funding from Kiva.

Mrs. Yim resides in Siem Reap province. She is a gasoline seller in her community and is earning approximately US $3 each day to cover her family’s needs. She has a life partner in her husband who provides ferry boat delivery services for all passengers and other villagers. They have a kid who is very young and depends on her care.

loans.use: to open a wedding salon.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
This is Marivic, 34, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is a mother to her three children, all still in school. She manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Marivic operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Marivic earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from the direct selling business, Marivic also earns by selling frozen food products. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 266 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and frozen food products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Marivic hopes to be able to expand soon, and send all her children to school all the way through college. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora  is 59 years-old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 12 children.
 
Leonora  has a shop that sells beverages, canned goods and breads. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 9,000 to buy canned goods, beverages and snacks to sell.

Leonora  has been a member of Kiva partner HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Leonora  hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages and snacks to sell.

loans.name: La

texts.en: La, 45 years-old, is making baskets to sell. Her husband is a car driver and their income is $9 per day. She has four children.  Two are studying and the other two are working in a restaurant earning $2 a day each. Every month, she has to spend $70 on food, $15 on electricity, $40 on school fees, and $30 on transportation. She would like to request a loan of $200 to buy material for making baskets. She like her career and wants to sell more baskets if she can have enough money to buy from other makers.

loans.use: to buy material for making baskets.

loans.name: Saron

texts.en: Saron, 33 years-old, is a vegetable seller and pig feeder. Her husband is a construction worker and their income is $11 per day. She has two children, four and one years old. Every month, she has to spend $50 on food, $5 on electricity, $15 on transportation, and $25 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to buy a motorbike for her husband to use to travel to work and to transport their vegetables to sell. She wants to repair her house when she has enough money and expects to send all of her children to study in the university.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband to travel to work and to sell their vegetables.

loans.name: Santiago

texts.en: Santiago is 60 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married, with 6 children. Santiago provides videoke or karaoke services. He has had this business for 5 years. He requested a loan of PHP 7,000 to buy tools & to pay for the utilities for the service.  Santiago has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Santiago hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools & to pay for the utilities for the service

loans.name: Dominggus

texts.en:
Dominggus is a 30 year-old-man and is working as a motorbike taxi driver. He is married to Serny, 22 years old, and has been blessed with one handsome boy named Justin, who is 2 years old . Dominggus and his family live at his parent’s house, as requested by his lonely widowed mother. As the backbone of his family, Dominggus prefers to work as a motorbike taxi driver to fulfill his family needs. 

Besides working as a motorbike taxi driver, Dominggus also has a small kiosk business operated by his wife. They utilized a small room at home to run the kiosk business. Dominggus is eager to build up a small kiosk in front of his house instead of the current one to make it more comfortable for the customers in purchasing their needs.  To do so, Dominggus is requesting a loan of IDR 3,000,000 from TLM.  He plans to buy the building material to build a simple kiosk. He and his family are hoping that TLM will help by providing him the loan.

Note: when the picture was taken, Dominggus was holding his son.

loans.use: To buy building material to build a simple kiosk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorbike and pigs to feed for selling

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen sells gasoline. Her husband repairs and washes motorbikes.  Their income is $8 per day.  She has 2 children, 8 and 1 year old.  Every month, she has to spend $60 on food, and $10 on other expenses. 

She would like a loan of $1200 to buy a motorbike and the tools for fixing the motorbike. Her husband's career is doing well because his many friends as a motor taxi driver have become his customers when they need to repair their motorbikes.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and the tools for fixing the motorbike

loans.name: Jeffrey

texts.en: Jeffrey is 35 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married, with 3 children.  Jeffrey has a shop that sells homemade souvenirs. He has had this business for 13 years. He requested a loan of PHP 7,000 to buy raw materials needed for making souvenirs.  Jeffrey has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Jeffrey hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy raw materials needed for making souvenirs

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en: Sokhom, 49 years old, is a motor taxi driver. His wife is a vegetable seller, and their income is $8 per day. He has two children, both of whom are studying. Every month, he has to spend $90 on food, $50 on school fees, $15 on transportation, and $5 on electricity. He would like to request a loan of $700 to buy a motorbike to run a motor taxi service. In the future he wants to expand his wife's business by buying more kinds of vegetables to sell. He wants to make more income for supporting his children at the university.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for a motor taxi service

loans.name: Herman

texts.en:
Herman is a 46-year-old-man married to Atriana, a 40-year-old lady. They have four children: 
• Fince, 21 years old, graduated from senior high school and now is working in another province. 
• Ovi, 17 years old, is studying at the first grade of senior high school.
• Filadelfia, 12 years old, is studying at the first grade of junior high school.
• Hesron, 7 years old, is studying at the first grade of elementary school.

Herman has a small kiosk to sell detergent, snacks, candies, rice, sugar, coffee, etc. He has been operating the business for years to support his family life and the education of his children. Besides operating the kiosk business, Herman is also planting vegetables such as mustard greens and spinach at his farm for his family's consumption. Sometimes Herman sells the vegetables at the local market to get more income for his family.

Herman is dreaming of adding more stocks to his kiosk to meet the demand of his customers. He is requesting a loan amounting to 10,000,000 Indonesia rupiahs (IDR) from TLM. He plans to buy kerosene, detergent, instant noodles and eggs as well as renovating his kiosk. He hopes to have an improvement in his business from the loan.

loans.use: To buy kerosene, detergent, noodles and eggs for his kiosk and to renovate his kiosk.

loans.name: Nolly

texts.en:
Nolly is 32 years old and married to Tessie, who is a business-minded woman. The couple is thankful because they have been blessed with four children. Through the sacrifices and patience of the couple, they are able to earn about 35,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) per cropping being farmers working in the Philippines.

Nolly grows rice and has been doing it for three years. Being a farmer is quite difficult due to insufficient funds for the maintenance of farm; that's why Nolly is encouraged to join the group of agricultural loan within their village to avail additional capital in maintaining his business. Nolly is asking for a loan of PHP 30,000, which will be used in buying additional fertilizer and insecticides. He hopes that he could supply all the needs of his family and make his farm more productive.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies such as fertilizer and insecticides.

loans.name: Savun

texts.en: Savun, 41 year old, is a fisherman. His wife makes fish paste to sell. Their income is $11 per day. He has five children. Three of the children are studying, one is working and one more fishes with him. Every month, he has to spend $50 on food, $10 on electricity, and $40 on school fees. He would like to request a loan of $1,000 to buy fishing equipment for doing fishing. He has a plan for his wife to buy clothes to sell in the market so that she can make more income than in her previous career. Then they would be able to send the rest of their children to study in the university when they finish high school.

loans.use: To buy fishing equipment

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: Neang rents boats. His wife sells gruel. Their income is $11 per day. He has three children. One of the children is studying and the other two are working in a grocery store with $2 per day for each. Every month, he has to spend $50 on food, $7 on electricity, and $11 on school fees. He would like to request a loan of $800 to buy wood to make a shelter for his boat for renting. He also can make income from his customers who come to rent his boats. They park their motorbikes at his place and he takes $0.10c for each motorbike. He plans to enlarge his house bigger than before and buy grocery goods for his wife so that she can sell two things at the same time: gruel and grocery goods.

loans.use: To buy wood to make a shelter for his boat

loans.name: Paulino

texts.en:
Paulino is 56 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with one child. 

Paulino provides motorela or habal-habal services. He has had this business for 10 years. He requested a loan of PHP 6,000 to buy tools & pay for the utilities needed for his motorela.

Paulino has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Paulino hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools & pay for the utilities needed for his motorela

loans.name: Mai

texts.en:
Mai is 58 years old and married. She lives in Ho Chi Minh City with her husband and two children. 

Mai's husband works as a ferryman. Mai earns money by running a general store in front of her house. She sells many kinds of goods such as confectionary, fast food and basic necessities to people in the local community. She has run the shop for five years.
