Mai intends to take a loan to purchase seasonal fruit and a greater variety of general goods to sell to her customers. She hopes that through the loan her business will bring in extra income to pay for her family expenses.

loans.use: to purchase more goods and seasonal fruit to sell

loans.name: Fedelina

texts.en:
This is Fedelina, 49, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Pedro, a foreman, and mother of five children. One of her children is married, two are working and the other two are students. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Fedelina operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Fedelina earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from the variety store business, Fedelina also earns by selling RTW products. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 1,400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 18,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and RTW products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Fedelina dreams of giving all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and RTW products to sell

loans.name: Ev

texts.en: From Kompong Speu province, Mrs. Ev, 50, is a widow and the mother of three children. Two of them are still teenagers and attend school and the other one is employed as a sewing worker. She has been farming since 1984 and she makes an average of $1.25 a day. In the past, Mrs. Ev has always hired the neighbor’s cows for the chore of plowing the farmland. Right now, she hopes to buy her own cows and that is why she is applying for a loan from Kiva. This will provide her with an additional fixed asset. With the rest of the funding, she will buy fertilizers to keep her crop growing well.

loans.use: to buy cows and fertilizers to keep her crop growing well.

loans.name: Norberta

texts.en:
This is Norberta, 49, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is a widow and a mother.  At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Norberta operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Norberta earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also earns through Electronic Cellular Phone Loading Station. What she basically does is to buy electronic cellular phone loads in huge amounts and then retail it for however much the customer is paying. Profit is generated depending on the networks policy of dealership. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 1,086 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 14,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Norberta hopes to be able to expand soon.  She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for groceries and other products to sell

loans.name: Risolat

texts.ru: Рисолат проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Ей 58 лет. Она замужем. У нее 8 детей. У них очень большая и дружная семья. Рисолат имеет высшее экономическое образование. Она по профессии проработала более 24 лет. На сегодняшний день Рисолат занимается торговлей на рынке "Дехкон". Она в основном занимается продажей пуговиц, бисера и тесьмы. Этим она зарабатывает и обеспечивает семью. Кредит берет для приобретения разных видов пуговиц, разноцветных ниток, бисера и тесьмы. Она хочет увеличить ассортимент своего товара.
texts.en: Risolat lives in Tursun-zoda.  She is 58 years old, married, and has eight children.  She has a large, loving family.  Risolat has a higher education as an economist.  She worked in her profession for more than 24 years.  Now, Risolat trades at the Dekhon market.  She primarily sells buttons, beads, and trims.  She is able to earn enough to support her family doing this.  She is taking out a loan to buy different kinds of buttons, different colored thread, beads, and trims.  She wants to increase the variety of her goods.

loans.use: to buy different kinds of buttons, different colored thread, beads, and trims.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 39 years old and lives in Palayan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is married and a mother of three school-aged dependents. Marilyn is a farmer. She owns and operates a business planting rice and harvesting palay. She has been engaged in this business for over five years. Every quarter, she earns a total of PHP 15,000 from this business. She has requested a loan of PHP 15,000 from GDMPC to pay for the labor cost for land preparation and to purchase seedlings to be planted this coming planting season.

Marilyn has been a member of GDMPC for one year. In the future, Marilyn hopes to gain more income from farming so that she can purchase additional land for her rice field.

loans.use: To pay for the labor for land preparation and to purchase seedlings.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is 51 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Anita has a shop that sells snacks, beverages & canned goods. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy additional snacks & beverages.

Anita has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Anita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional snacks & beverages

loans.name: Conrada

texts.en:
Conrada is 54 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Conrada has a retail shop that sells beverages, canned goods & snacks. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Conrada is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Conrada hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie is 41 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Rosie has a retail shop that sells snacks, breads & beverages. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Rosie is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Rosie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is 20 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is single. 

Joy has a shop that sells snacks, beverages & canned goods. He has had this business for two years. He requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages. Joy is a male contrary to his female-like name.

Joy is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Joy hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Anna Rose

texts.en:
Anna Rose is 29 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. 

Anna Rose makes and sells souvenirs like necklaces made from seashells. She has had this business for one year. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy materials needed to make souvenirs.

Anna Rose is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Anna Rose hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy materials needed lo make souvenirs

loans.name: Soeum

texts.en: To earn a living, Mrs. Soeum sells some study materials and other merchandise to students who attend her local school. She shares responsibility with Mr. Soeun, her husband, who always goes to the river to catch fresh fish using a variety of fishing tools. Mrs. Soeum has been running her retail business since 2010, earning  around $4 each day to cover expenses for the family. Mrs. Soeum now has four young children; all of them are students in the local school. Mrs. Soeum would like to request a loan to buy more merchandise to sell. With the rest of funding, she will buy some fishing equipment for her husband to catch more fish.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise to sell and to buy some fishing equipment for her husband to catch more fish.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion is 48 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children.
 
Concepcion has a retail shop that sells canned goods, beverages and snacks. She has had this business for five years. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, detergents and beverages.

Concepcion is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, detergents and beverages

loans.name: Nozihol

texts.ru: Нозихол проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Ей 52 года. Она вдова, у нее один ребенок. Нозихол имеет среднее образование. Она занимается торговлей. В основном она ходит по домам и показывает свой товар. В этом ей помогает ее дочь. Она в этой области уже 10 лет. За эти годы у нее появились постоянные клиенты. Нозихол берет кредит для покупки оптом тканей.
texts.en: Nozihol lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. She is 52 years old. She is a widow and has one child. Nozihol has secondary education. She does sales. Mainly she goes from house to house and shows her merchandise. Her daughter is also helping her. Nozihol has been in this business for ten years. During these years she got many regular customers. Nozihol is taking out the loan to buy fabrics in wholesale.

loans.use: to buy fabrics in wholesale

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel is 31 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed.
 
Maricel has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for five years. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Maricel is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Naseeran's Group

texts.en:
Naseeran is a widow; she lost her husband as a result of a sudden death. It was a very difficult time for her, but she never lost heart and worked very hard to raise her children. Now her children have become young [adults] and started work. Unfortunately she couldn’t provide her sons education so they remain illiterate. 

Her eldest son has a motorbike showroom business. The second one has a hosiery business and the third one operates a canteen in a nearby school. Her daughter is a student.  

Naseeran has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner Asasah for her son who wants to buy another motorbike for his showroom. This will help him expand his business and earn more profits. He has been doing this business for the past eight years and Naseeran is confident that an investment will help him increase his profits by expanding his business. She is a regular client of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself a very responsible client by paying her installments on time and by attending every meeting.

loans.use: to buy another motorbike for a motorbike showroom business.

loans.name: Ashurali

texts.ru: Ашурали житель города Куляб. Возраст, 52 года. Женат. Имеет шестерых детей. Его жена домохозяйка. Сам он занимается производством. Он у себя дома открыл цех, где производит сахар для продажи. Этим видом деятельности Ашурали занимается 5 лет. Он берет кредит для приобретения новой посуды и необходимых инструментов.
texts.en: Ashurali lives in the town of Kulob. He is 52 years old. He is married and has six children. His wife is a homemaker. He is in the production business. He opened a shop in his house where he makes sugar for sale. Ashurali has been in this business for five years. He is taking out the loan to buy new dishware and necessary tools.

loans.use: to buy new dishware and necessary tools

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is a married man with five children, all of whom attend school. He lives at a house that they own; it has electricity but does not have piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for the family.

For the past 10 years, Samuel has operated a retail shop business, selling to his neighbours and passersby. He faces the major challenge of seasonality in his business. During the months from January to August, demand for goods is higher hence he is able to make more profits in his business. 

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, Samuel wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for sale.

loans.name: Obama Group

texts.en:
Jibileth, who is in her early 40s, is married with three children who go to school.  She has been running a food vendor business for five years now.  She works from 6am to 11am (for five hours) daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be her seventh loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to pay school fees, household expenses and also kept on increasing her food stock and has paid back her loans successfully.  She hopes for a loan to buy rice, maize, ground nuts and millet.  What she does is mix and grind all of them together.  She puts some aside for selling as dry food and with the other portion she makes porridge which she sells from door to door. Her dream is to one day build her own house.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Obama" which has a total of 16 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy rice, maize, ground nuts, and millet.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is a married woman with eight children, four girls and four boys. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Chizi operates a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces the major challenges of the high cost of transportation and lack of a ready market for her business. 

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, baking powder and cooking fat oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She dreams of expanding her business to make more profits and to educate her children in the future.

loans.use: To purchase maize flour, wheat flour, baking powder and cooking fat oil.

loans.name: Hamisi

texts.en:
Hamisi is a married man with four children, one of whom attends school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.  His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Hamisi has operated a greengrocery business for the past two years, selling as wholesale to retailers, neighbours and passersby. He faces the major challenge of seasonality in his business. Hamisi dreams of expanding and establishing another grocery shop in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 loan, he wants to purchase sacks of vegetables, onions and tomatoes. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables, onions and tomatoes.

loans.name: Consejo

texts.en:
Consejo is 46 years old and married. She has three children aged 21, 16 and 13. Consejo is a farmer who tills land in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She grows rice to sell to rice traders. 

Consejo works hard to support her family. She has requested a loan to gain financial support for her business. She plans to use her loan to purchase five bags of fertilizer and other farm inputs. Consejo hopes to have a progressive business that will help raise her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase five bags of fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ntungamo Bakyara Tuhirirwe Group

texts.en:
Ruth is a 48-year-old married woman with five children aged between 8 and 15 years of age all of whom go to school. Ruth owns a guest house and therefore offers accommodation to the traders who come to town and to tourists who sometimes trickle into the local area to see some of Ntungamo's fascinating scenery. Ruth loudly explains how happy she is to have managed to set up and run a good accommodation facility for five years with a steady income of 150,000 Ugandan shillings as average weekly profits. She, however, stresses that it has not been easy but through hard work, valuing customers and above all, providing comfortable accommodation and an environment that has made it a place to think about as a priority for accommodation in the area. 

This determined woman, with a temperament for work, also participates in agriculture particularly in banana growing and her goal in future is to open up a modern restaurant within the guest house to sell her bananas since she has a ready market. With the Kiva loan, Ruth intends to expand and modernize her banana plantation by mulching and applying fertilisers for better yields.

loans.use: To mulch and apply fertilisers to her banana plantation for better yields.

loans.name: Mwale Group

texts.en:
Halima, who is in her early 50s, is married with two adult children and two grandchildren who go to school. She has had a charcoal store since 1998.  She works from 6am to 7pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be her seventh loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy land, to make bricks for building her house, for school fees and household expenses and has paid back all of her loans successfully. She hopes for a loan to buy more sacks of charcoal.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Mwale" which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 53-year-old married man, father of two children. He has worked in construction for the past 31 years. He started to work on his own in 1982 because he was planning to learn how to deA. with cement and to move along with planning his future and so it was.

Mahmoud is borrowing from A. Majmoua - Kiva's partner - for the first time. He is requesting a loan in order to buy new tools necessary for his business. Most of his customers are neighboring villagers and contractors. He is a man with a good reputation and is recommended to others to deA. with since it's hard these days to find a trustful person who works with a conscience.

Mahmoud hopes to stay healthy and capable of working to provide his family with the necessities for living.

loans.use: To buy new tools necessary for his business

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is a 27-year-old married woman. She has two young children aged five and two.

Elsie is a farmer. She has been growing rice and vegetables for six years now. Her husband is also a farmer and is the one who mainly manages their farm. Elsie does her best to keep their farm productive. She said she wants her family to be happy and healthy always.

Elsie has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. She hopes to be able to save for her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Amani Group

texts.en:
Juma, who is in his early 20s, is married.  He has been running a genge (fruits and vegetables) business for two years now.  He works from 5am to 6pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit. 

This will be his first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, which he wants to use to buy more fruits and vegetables for him to sell. His dream is to one day buy land.

He will share this loan with his loan group "Amani" which has a total of 15 members, who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To increase his stock of fruits and vegetables.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, aged 48, is an enterprising business-lady. She is married to John and they are blessed with two children aged 32 and 24 years.  She has been selling fish for the past three years earning monthly income of KES 20,000 which she uses to support her family.

Mary is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD, after being introduced by a KADET staff member. She will use the loan to boost her business by buying a fridge to store her fish.

With the anticipated profit she will open a greengrocery. Her hope is to prosper more in business.

loans.use: To boost her business by buying a fridge to store her fish

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia is a married woman with four children, all of whom have graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Sofia has operated a retail shop business, selling household consumables like maize flour, wheat flour and sugar. Her potential customers are neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of theft because of insecurity in her area of operation. In the future, she dreams of expanding her business and establishing a posho mill business (a mill that grinds wheat and maize into flour).

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat oil.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy, aged 28, is a single lady who does dressmaking. She has been doing the business for two years and earns a monthly profit of KES 18,000.

This is her first loan with KADET LTD. She will use the loan funds to buy materials for making dresses.

Lucy intends to use the expected profits to open another dressmaking shop and hopes to own a piece of land in future.

loans.use: To buy materials for making dresses

loans.name: Enrequita

texts.en:
Enrequita is a 63-year-old married woman from the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She is into the hog-raising business. She has built a small backyard piggery where she raises her pigs. Enrequita also grows vegetables to sell at the market.

Enrequita needs a loan to purchase farm fertilizers and additional piglets to raise. She hopes to have a stable business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase farm fertilizers and additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Ma.neniere

texts.en:
Ma.Neniere is married with six children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Ma.Neniere is 50 years old and has two children who are in school.

Ma.Neniere has a fish-vending business in the Philippines. Ma.Neniere requested a 12,000 Philippines pesos loan through NWTF to purchase more fish to sell to customers.

Ma.Neniere has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, Ma.Neniere would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell to customers.

loans.name: Maideen Glacier

texts.en:
Maideen Glacier is 21 years old, married and has two children. 

Maideen Glacier is in the agricultural business, farming rice in the Philippines. Maideen Glacier requested a 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Maideen Glacier has been farming rice for two years now and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Maideen Glacier would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is 38 years old and married. She has two children aged 12 and 10. Geraldine’s husband works as a farmer and driver.

Geraldine has had a sari-sari (variety) store business for 15 years. She sells items like noodles and canned goods to the people in her community. She sometimes helps her husband grow rice crops at their farm. They also grow cassava plants on a part of their land.

Geraldine requested this loan to buy farm inputs like fertilizers and seeds. She also plans to buy more items to sell such as sugar, shampoo and soap. Geraldine hopes to have a stable income that will sustain her family and her children’s education.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers and items to sell such as sugar, shampoo and soap

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is a 27-year-old businessman; he is married to Ruth who is a housewife. They are blessed with one child aged five years old. Samuel has been in the business of baking cakes for the past five years with a monthly income of KES 12,000 which he uses to support his family members.

He is a new client and is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD, after being introduced to KADET LTD by a KADET staff member. 

Samuel will use the loan to boost his baking business by buying a motorbike for transporting cakes to his customers. With the anticipated profit from the business he will educate his child. His hope is to open a mini supermarket.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for transporting cakes

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol works hard to support her family. Mirasol is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Mirasol requested a 11,000 Philippines pesos loan through NWTF to buy fishing materials.

Mirasol has been in this business for four years.

In the future, Mirasol would like to save money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials.

loans.name: Chamwino Group

texts.en:
Sophia, who is in her early 40s, is single with two children and two grand childrren who are still at school. She has been a food vendor for 14 years.  She works from 6am to 8pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. 

This will be her second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loan to increase her capital and bought more food stock. She has repaid her loan successfully. She wants a loan to buy more food stock for her business. Her dream is to one day be able to make her business grow. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Chamwino" which has a total of 16 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more food stock for her business.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph, aged 30, is married to Rahab and they are blessed with two children aged four and two. He runs a boutique which has been in operation for two years. The business earns him a monthly income of KES 30,000.

This is his first loan from KADET LTD. He will use the loan funds to buy more clothes for resale. Joseph intends to open another boutique for his wife using the anticipated profits and hopes to grow his business and own a piece of land in future.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Mary Joy

texts.en:
Mary Joy is a hardworking entrepreneur who has operated a blacksmith business in the Philippines for 5 years. She is borrowing PHP 19,500 through NWTF to purchase additional steel and other materials for her business.

Mary Joy earns additional income from a tricycle transport business. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: To purchase additional steel and other materials

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, age 33, is married to Beatrice who does farming, and they are blessed with one child, age three. He operates a motorcycle transport business that has been in operation for two years. The business earns him a monthly income of about 22,500 KES (~$253).

This is his first loan from KADET LTD. He will use the loan funds to service his motorbikes. John intends to buy another motorbike from the anticipated profits and hopes to own a fleet of commercial vehicles in future.

loans.use: To service his motorbikes.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, age 21, is married to Hannah, and they are blessed with one child who is nine months old. John operates a motorcycle transport business that has been in operation for two years. The business earns him a monthly income of KES 21,000 (~$236).

This is his first loan term with KADET LTD. He will use the loan funds to buy another motorcycle. John hopes to own a fleet of commercial vehicles in future.

loans.use: To buy another motorbike.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 33 years old and married, with four children. She works hard to provide for her family. Jocelyn has operated a variety store in the Philippines for 10 years. She also earns an income from selling frozen foods.

Jocelyn has requested a PHP 21,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell. She has already borrowed and repaid 9 loans from NWTF. Jocelyn hopes to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Larry

texts.en: Larry, 46 years of age, is married, and they were blessed with 5 children. Larry is has been a farmer for almost 19 years. He grows rice. His net income last cropping was 25,000 PHP (~$600). He's asking for a loan for 25,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers and insecticides for his farm. Larry would like to maintain his relationship with Kiva and ASKI MFI to request larger loans so that he can grow his agricultural business and supplement his family's daily needs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.name: Raylen

texts.en:
Raylen is a hardworking entrepreneur who has operated a tricycle transport business in the Philippines for 5 years. She earns additional income from fish vending.

Raylen is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to purchase spare parts for her motorcycle transport business. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for motorcycle repairs

loans.name: Rogelia

texts.en:
Rogelia is 58 years old and married with five children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Rogelia runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a 24,500 Philippines pesos loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell like canned goods and other groceries in her sari-sari store.

Rogelia has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as milk, noodles, spices, oil, etc. 

In the future, Rogelia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Arnolfo

texts.en:
Arnolfo is 42 years old and married to Agnes. He is thankful because he is blessed with 2 children. They are generally school-aged.

Arnolfo grows rice and has been doing it for 18 years. He is grateful because through his patience in maintaining his rice farm he is able to earn PHP 60,000 (~$1410) per cropping. Due to the high cost of basic commodities and expensive farm supplies, he is in need of additional capital. In this regard, he is requesting a loan of PHP 50,000 which will be used to buy fertilizer and insecticides for his farm.

In the future, Arnolfo hopes to avail loan requests to further improve his farm and also to increase his profit.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticides for his farm.

loans.name: Buzaniro Biika Oguze Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
Prisca, a 32-year-old married woman with 2 children, operates a coffee and maize trading activity in Kanungu, which she has run for 3 years. She happily speaks well about her experience in this business as it has brought her all the necessary skills in the coffee and maize business and has enabled her to earn 120,000 Ugandan shillings weekly. 

Prisca, who is known for her hard work, is asking for a loan that she will use for expanding her business. She has benefited by buying more land for her agricultural activity and she hopes to buy more coffee and maize for resale.

loans.use: To buy more coffee and maize for resale.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 42-year-old widow with 6 children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. She has been raising pigs for 7 years and earns additional income from ice retailing.

Sarah is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs. She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Sarapia

texts.en:
Sarapia, 49 years old, is married and has 5 children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Sarapia has operated a spice and vegetable vending business in the Philippines for 10 years. She has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock of spices and vegetables to sell. Sarapia would like to build and expand her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of spices and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Mazam

texts.ru: Мазам проживает в городе Куляб. Она замужем. У неё 8 детей. Она имеет среднее образование. Уже семнадцать лет Мазам торгует на базаре женским нижним бельём. Она берет кредит для покупки пижам, маек и шорт.
texts.en: Mazam lives in the town of Kulob. She is married. She has eight children. She has secondary education. Mazam has been selling women's undergarments on the market for seventeen years. She is taking out the loan to buy pajamas, tank-tops and shorts.

loans.use: to buy pajamas, tank-tops and shorts

loans.name: Rwakitami Bakyara Women's Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
Mable is the leader of the Rwakitami women's group in Ntungamo. The hard working and flexible lady is 44 years old and married with 10 children, 7 of whom are still in school. She deals in the sale of produce which include beans, millet, maize and so on, and she operates from Ngoma where she employs one person to help with her business. She is able to generate 200,000/= as profits weekly and this is beneficial to her family. 

She is also involved in the sale of matooke (steamed green bananas or plantain) and milk from her farm, and these supplement her income. Her dream is to be able to build a better residential house and educate her children. Ever since Mable started taking loans, she has improved her livelihood and the standard of living of her family. She needs a loan to be able to buy more millet, beans and maize for resale.

loans.use: To buy more beans, millet and maize for increased stock.

loans.name: Sharifa

texts.en:
Sharifa is a widow with two children, one of whom attends school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past seven years, she has operated a bakery business, selling bread at the market to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she also sells clothes which contributes to her income. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing real estate houses in the future.

With the 15,000 KES she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, beans, cooking oil and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, beans, cooking oil and sugar.

loans.name: Deo

texts.en:
Deo is 55 years old and married with 4 children, 1 son and 3 daughters. She lives with her husband and children in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband works as a hired motorbike driver. 

Deo earns an income to support her family by selling fabric in a small market. She has done this for the past 15 years. 

She would like to take a loan to buy a greater quantity of different fabrics and clothing materials to sell to her customers. She hopes that this will better meet the needs of her customers and will attract more customers to her store. Deo hopes that through the loan she will be able to increase her income to more adequately cover family expenses.

loans.use: to buy fabric and clothing materials to sell in her store.

loans.name: Believe Group

texts.en:
Abdallah, who is in his late twenties, is married with one small child.  He has been selling secondhand clothes for six months now.  He works from 5am to 7pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be his 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, which he wants to use for buying more secondhand clothes to sell.  His dream is to one day build his own house.

He will share this loan with his loan group, "Believe", which has a total of 19 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school while one is still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a clothing business, selling swimming costumes and khangas (traditional colorful fabric worn as a wrap) along the beach showers to tourists. In addition she also has a table mat weaving business which contributes another source of income. She faces the major challenge of seasonality. During the cold winter season the availability of tourists at the beach is lower, providing less sales volume. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing a boutique shop in the future.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase bundles of clothes for resale. She decided to access funds to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Araksi

texts.en: Please meet Araksi. She and her family live in a remote village outside Talin, Armenia. Araksi and her husband have five children and several grandchildren. Araksi’s husband is a wounded war veteran, and Araksi refers to him as a real hero. Together they raise animals, grow fruits and grass—just enough to keep the cattle and the family fed. Since the Soviet Union disintegrated, income amongst rural Armenian farmers has become unpredictable. In addition, Araksi noted that the weather has been particularly bad for Armenian farmers this year. Hail, strong winds and rain have ruined much of the fruit crop, the house and the barn ceiling. Nonetheless, Araksi wants to be positive. Araksi has applied for a loan to buy a reaper (grass-cutting machine). The grass-cutting machine will make it easier to raise cattle and pigs at her age, as these animals eat grass. The ability to take care of more livestock should increase this family’s monthly income.

loans.use: to pay for a grass-cutting machine

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a single woman with four children.  Two attend school while the others are still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, Mwanatumu has operated a paraffin-selling business, selling from home to neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of increasing prices of paraffin. She dreams of establishing a paraffin shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase 180 liters of paraffin to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase 180 liters of paraffin to sell.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a single woman with two children who both graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a business selling baobab fruit, the powdered pith of the baobab nut.  Halima sells at the market to neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the dry summer season, the supply of baobab fruit declines, compared to cold winter seasons. She dreams of establishing a baobab fruit shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000 loan, Halima wants to purchase sacks of baobab fruit  to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of baobab fruit to sell.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is 45 years old.  She is engaged in  a hog-raising business. She raises her pigs in her backyard and sells them at the market. Evangeline’s husband is a farmer. She helps him grow rice crops and sell their harvest.

Evangeline requested a loan to purchase pig feed and vitamins, rice seeds and fertilizer. She hopes that her business and her husband's farming will grow. She also hopes that her family’s living conditions will improve.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed and vitamins, rice seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda is 50 years old and married.  She has 3 children ages 22, 19 and 13 years old.

Melinda has been engaged in farming for 20 years.  She and her husband own and till land in their town Sto. Niño, South Cotabato.  They grow rice and corn crops to sell. 

Melinda also decided to put up a small sari-sari store to help in their daily needs.  She sells vinegar, sugar and other daily use products.  Melinda requested this loan to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers.  She hopes to be able to sustain her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is a married woman with 3 children ages 18, 12 and 11 years old.  She and her husband are both farmers.  They grow rice and vegetables at their land.  Sonia also runs their small sari-sari store.  She sells items like shampoo, detergent soap, biscuits and others.

Sonia requested a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers.  She hopes this loan will help increase their harvest.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a furniture-making business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to purchase additional materials for her furniture making business.

Carmelita has been in this business for four years. Carmelita earns more income from her sari-sari store.

Carmelita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials for her business

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en:
Josephine is 47 years old.  She is a hard working and honest business woman.  She is married and blessed with three children aged: 27, 25, and 23 years old.  

For the last 8 years, she has been making a living by selling snacks.  She wants in the next 5 years to have expanded into a bakery so that she is able to become financially stable.  She is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings to buy wheat flour and cooking oil.  Thanks to Faulu Kenya she has been able to educate her children

loans.use: to buy wheat flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more foodstuffs for her shop

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella, 39 years of age, is married and has two school-aged children.  Bella owns and operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals.  Bella has been engaged in this business for almost 5 years and earns approximately 22,000 PHP monthly.

Bella joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She's asking for a loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients for her food vending business.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients for her food vending business

loans.name: Leslie

texts.en:
Leslie is married and has not been blessed with an offspring.  She is 27 years old and lives in Western Poblacion, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental: Philippines.

Leslie has a retail business to earn a living.  She sells cosmetics and beauty products in the local community.  She sells, perfume, cologne, make-up and other body make overs.  She has run her business for over five years now.  She earns PHP 3,000.00 a month from this work. 

She has requested a loan of PHP 15,000.00 to purchase cosmetics and beauty products to sell.  Leslie has been member of GDMPC for one year.  In the future, Lislie hopes to gain more income and have her own cosmetics boutique in the town.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and beauty products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase three calves

loans.name: Isabelo

texts.en:
Isabelo is 49 years old and lives in San Vicente Bajo, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. He is married with four school-aged dependents.

Isabelo is a motorcycle taxi driver. He owns and operates a service-based business, providing passenger services in the local community. He has been engaged in this business for over three years. He earns a total of 6,000 PHP a month from this business. He has requested a loan of 20,000 PHP at GDMPC to purchase tires and spare parts and to pay for the labor cost in motorcycle repair and maintenance.

Isabelo has been a member of GDMPC for one year. In the future, Isabelo hopes to gain more income from this business to purchase an additional motorcycle for transport.

loans.use: to purchase tires and spare parts, and to pay for the labor cost of motorcycle repair and maintenance

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita is married and the mother of four adult dependents. She is 62 years old and lives in San Vicente Bajo, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines.

Perlita has a small market at home to earn a living. She sells assorted food items, soft drinks, rice and corn grains and canned goods. She has run her business for three years. She earns 3,000 PHP a month from these business. She has requested a loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC to purchase soft drinks and rice and corn grains to sell.

Perlita has been member of GDMPC for three years. In the future, Perlita hopes to gain more income to purchase more products to sell.

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks, rice and corn grains to sell

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is a married woman and the mother of one school-aged child. She is 47 years old and lives in Upper Lancangan, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines.

Marilou has a retail shop at home to earn a living. She sells different food products, refreshments and feed for the animals. She has been engaged in this retail business for five years. She earns a total of 3,000 PHP a month from these activities. She has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP at GDMPC to purchase dried fish to sell.

Marilou has been a member of GDMPC for two years. In the future, Marilou hopes to gain more income to purchase more available products to sell in the community.

loans.use: to purchase dried fish to sell

loans.name: Zarina's Group

texts.en:
Zarina is a working lady sewing clothes for her neighbor clients. She is very skillful in her work and her customers like her designs. They give her regular orders every month. Zarina has four children. All of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. Her husband is a contractor and builds houses and buildings on contract. Both Zarina and her husband work very hard so they can afford their children's school fees and put three meals on the table. 

Zarina has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner Asasah for the further expansion of her sewing business. With this loan, she will buy a new sewing machine that will allow her to finish the orders on time and earn better profits. She is very experienced in her work as she has been doing it for the past 10 years. She is confident that a loan will be productive for her. 

Zarina is a regular client of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In previous loan years, she has established good credit behavior and never missed a meeting. In the photo, the lady with a book (an Asasah passbook) is Zarina.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine for a sewing business.

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Agé de 39 ans, Kokou est revendeur de charbon de bois  et d’igname à domicile. Il a commencé son activité en  1992 et s’approvisionne aussi bien à Atakpamé  qu’à  Danyi dans le KLOTO. Kodjo est marié à une revendeuse  et est père de 02 enfants. Ce deuxième crédit va lui permettre de stocker plus d’ignames et de sacs de charbon de bois pour la revente.
texts.en:
Kokou is 39 years old. He sells charcoal and yams from his home, an activity started in 1992. He gets his stock both in Atakpamé and in Danyi, in the Kloto region. 

Kokou is married to a reseller and he is the father of two children. This second loan will allow him to stock up on yams and sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.use: to buy yams and sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Genara

texts.en:
Genara works hard to support her family. Genara is married and has a sand and gravel business in the Philippines.

Genara requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy more sand and gravel to sell.

Genara has been in this business for 22 years now.

In the future, Genara would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more sand and gravel to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Golibchon

texts.ru: Голибчон проживает в районе Хамадони. Холост. У него среднее техническое образование. Голибчон уже два года как ремонтирует автомобили. Он кредит берет для приобретения нового оборудования для ремонта машин.
texts.en: Golibchon lives in the Hamadoni district.  He is single.  He has a secondary technical education.  Golibchon has been repairing cars for two years.  He is requesting this loan to purchase new equipment for auto repairs.

loans.use: to purchase new auto repair equipment

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 24 years old. He is a hardworking and honest businessman who is married with no children. He has been making a living for the last 4 years by selling clothes. He wants, in the next 5 years, to be making sales on wholesale terms so that he will be able to realize his dream of expanding his business beyond his county.

He is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more trousers for sale. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, he has now learned good customer relations and how to save.

loans.use: to buy more trousers for sale

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Revendeur d’huile à moteur (activité qu’il mène depuis 2004) à ADIDOGOME, Komi est père de 02 enfants. Il sollicite ce prêt pour acheter plus de marchandises à LOME pour revendre afin de voir sa famille prospérer dans de bonnes conditions. Deux personnes l’aident dans l’exercice de cette activité.
texts.en:
Komi sells motor oil in Adidogomé, an activity he started in 2004. There are two people helping him carry out his business. He has two children. 

Komi is seeking this loan to replenish his stock in Lomé. His sales will help him to provide his family with good living conditions.

loans.use: to buy 12 cartons of motor oil for resale

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en: Rashid is a 21-year-old enterprising man living in a rented house in Hioma, Uganda. For 2 years, Rashid has been dealing in the textile business and started with 450,000 shillings but he currently has capital of one million. He faces a challenge of seasonal changes and his desire is to operate from sheltered premises. Rashid needs the loan capability to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda is 38 years old and married with three children.

Luzviminda works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. in her sari-sari store.

Luzviminda has borrowed and paid back eight loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 10 years and earns additional income from pig fattening.

Luzviminda aspires to save enough money to expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy items like shampoo and groceries to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Marites works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines and earns additional income from pig fattening.  Marites is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

Marites has been sustaining her business activities through her past eight loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her food vending business

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is 26 years old. She is married and blessed with three children. She has been operating a general shop for the last seven years to meet her family's needs. In the next five years, she wants to own a supermarket so that she is able to grow businesswise. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy sugar, rice, cooking oil, etc. She is grateful to Faulu Kenya for advancing her finances to use in her business.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Kodjo est un homme âgé de45 ans. Il est marié å une revendeuse. Il a 02 enfants.  
Kodjo travaille comme éleveur de poules depuis 2006. Il élève les poules et vend à toutes personnes. Il achète les produits à Lomé.
Kodjo a requis son 1er cycle de crédit à WAGES afin d’acheter 10 sachets d’ingrédients servant aux nourritures des poules, 23 boites de produits vétérinaires et 10 boites de vitamines.
texts.en: Kodjo is a 45-year-old man. He is married to a retailer and has two children. He has been working as a chicken farmer since 2006. He raises hens and sells them to anyone. He purchases his supplies in Lomé, the capital of Togo. Kodjo has requested his first loan cycle from WAGES in order to buy 10 packets of hen feed, 23 containers of veterinarian products, and 10 bottles of vitamins.

loans.use: to buy 10 packets of ingredients as food for hens and some vitamins

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more cereals for increased stock and resale.

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a single woman with three school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, she has operated a grocery selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transporting stock to her place of operation. She dreams of expanding her retail shop business in the future.

With the KES 10,000 she wants to purchase crates of tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase crates of tomatoes, potatoes and onions.

loans.name: Deogratious

texts.en:
Deogratious is 22 years old and married with two children, age 5 and  2 years old. They are living in a rented house in Hioma, Uganda. He is solely charged with the responsibility of looking after the family, and his dream is to build a house in the next five years. 

For five years, Deogratious has been dealing in the textile business. He started with 500,000 UGX. 

He faces a challenge of defaulting payment by credit customers but he hopes to expand his business to a wholesale status. Deogratious needs the loan to buy clothes to resell.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a married man with 12 children, three of whom attend school. He lives at his own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees for his children. 

For the past seven years, he has operated a farming business, selling at the market to his neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge of seasonality. During hot summer season, he experiences droughts that lead to low production of produce. He dreams of becoming a big supplier of farm produce in the future.

With the KES 60,000 he wants to purchase six cattle's each costing Kshs 10,000 for his farming business. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase six cattle's each costing Kshs 10,000 for his farming business.

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol is 35 years old and married to Nthiwa. They do not have children yet.

For 11 years Carol has been operating a pharmacy in Tala, and she earns an income of KES 15,000 per month. She sells her products to customers who come to Tala town.

Carol was introduced to KADET Ltd. by a credit officer and she is applying for her third loan of KES 50,000. She plans to use the entire loan amount to purchase assorted medicine for sale.
 
She will use the anticipated profit to invest back into the business, and in the future she plans to open a bigger business.

loans.use: To buy assorted medicine for sale.

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a grocery business, selling in a shop to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of theft in her business. She dreams of expanding her business to a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married woman who lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase one bundle of green vegetables, sacks of ground nuts and potatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of green vegetables, sacks of ground nuts and potatoes.

loans.name: Sam Im

texts.en:
Sam Im is a construction worker, while his wife, Chhean, is a garment worker. They have been married since 2000 and have two children, one son and one daughter. The family lives in a village about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sam Im is asking for a loan of $400 to add to his own money to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.use: to add to his own money to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Jeanine

texts.en:
Jeanine is a Rwandan entrepreneur married to a driver. They have four children between the ages of 4 and 13 years old. All of them are in school.

Since 2003, Jeanine has been selling charcoal. Her business has expanded, and in the time she once sold 20 sacks, she now sells 140.

She will use this loan to purchase more charcoal to sell to meet the growing demand in her business.

With the profits from her business, she plans to accumulate savings and renovate her family’s house. Her goal as a business woman is to become a wholesaler and run her own store.

loans.use: to buy charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Dioscora

texts.en:
Dioscora is single, 57 years old and lives in Causwagan, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte.

Dioscora's  business is a general store, and she has had this business for 30 years. Each month, she earns 10,000 PHP doing this work. 

She has requested a loan for 20,000 PHP to purchase more stocks of products to sell.

Dioscora joined PMPC just this year.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Badiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Badiya (qui veut dire parenté en Mandingue) a été créé le 15 Juin 2009 lors de l’inauguration leur banc villageois. Il compte 27 femmes qui habitent toutes le même quartier, solidarité et entre aide caractérise ce groupe. Elles ont des restaurants et font du petit commerce.

Madame Yandé (debout en cinquième position de la gauche vers la droite) est responsable. Elle est âgée de 35 ans, est célibataire et sans enfant cependant elle prend en charge sa mère  et ses sœurs.


Elle est gestion d’un restaurant dans son quartier, activité qu’elle exerce depuis trois ans.

Son  nouveau prêt va lui permettre de renforcer son activité par l’achat  d’un stock de riz et divers produits pour son restaurant.

Les bénéfices lui serviront d’augmenter son épargne en partie et de améliorer les conditions de vie de sa mère et de ses sœurs.
texts.en:
The Badiya (meaning 'relations' in Mandinka) group was created on 15 June 2009 after the launch of their local village loan fund. It comprises 27 women who all live in the same area; solidarity and mutual help characterize this group. The members have restaurants and run small retail businesses.

Ms. Yandé (standing fifth from the left in the photo) is the leader. She is 35 years old, unmarried, and has no children, but takes care of her mother and her sisters.

She has been managing a restaurant in her area for three years.

Her new loan will allow her to strengthen her business by stocking rice and various products for her restaurant.

The profits will serve in part to increase her savings and to improve the living conditions of her mother and her sisters.

loans.use: To strengthen her business by stocking rice and various products for her restaurant.

loans.name: Bakidioto 02 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Bakidioto 02 a été créé le 10 Décembre  2003 à l’inauguration de leur banc villageois. Il compte 14 femmes qui vivent dans le même village. Ayant comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Sagna  (assise à l’extrême droite), est  responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 39ans. Elle est  mariée et mère de six enfants. 

Elle  vend de la patte d’arachide à travers les différents marchés hebdomadaires des villages environnants. Cette activité elle l’a pratique depuis plus de 05 ans.

Ce nouveau lui permettra d’acheter de la patte d’arachide pour la revente.

Avec les bénéfices qu’elle tirera de son activité, elle compte soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge des enfants.
texts.en:
The Bakidioto 2 group was created on 10 December 2003 after the establishment of their local village loan fund. It comprises 14 women who live in the same town. Their main activity is running small retail businesses.

Ms. Sagna (sitting all the way on the right) is the group leader. She is 39 years old, married, and has six children.

She sells peanut paste at the various weekly markets in the surrounding towns. She has been involved in this activity for over five years.

This new loan will allow her to buy peanut paste for resale.

With the profit she will make from her business, she intends to support her husband in taking care of the children.

loans.use: To buy peanut paste for resale.

loans.name: Mwanafatime

texts.en:
Mwanafatime is married and has four children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children. 

Mwanafatime operates a lesos, or Khangas (brightly colored patterned cloth, commonly worn as a wrap or scarf)) selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation due to the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of establishing a shop to sell in the future.

Mwanafatime is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES, which she will use to purchase bundles of lesos for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of lesos (Khangas) for sale.

loans.name: Bakidioto 01 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Bakidioto 01 a été créé le 10 Décembre  2003 à l’inauguration de leur banc villageois. Il est composé de 17 femmes qui sont issues du même village. Très solidaire entre elles.ces femmes ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Boiro (assise à l’extrême droite), est  responsable du groupe et est âgée de 63 ans. Elle est  mariée et a en charge actuellement que 08 de ses  petits enfants. 

Elle est gérante d’une boutique de détail dans son village, activité qu’elle mène depuis plus d’une décennie.

Ce nouveau prêt lui permettra de recharger sa boutique pour les différents produits de consommation courante.

Avec les bénéfices qu’elle tirera de son activité, elle tient à assurer la scolarité de ses petits enfants.
texts.en:
Bakidioto 01 is a group that was created on December 10, 2003 at the inauguration of their Banc Villageois. With much solidarity among them, these women work principally in small-scale commerce. 

Ms. Boiro (seated at the far right in the photo) is the group's official. She is 63 years old, married, and currently responsible for eight of her grandchildren. She is the manager of a retail store in her village. It is a business that she has been running for over a decade. This new loan will enable her to restock her store with various typical goods. With the profits she will derive from her business, she expects to ensure her grandchildren's education.

loans.use: to restock her store with various typical consumer products

loans.name: Sop Sa Jëker Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Sop Sa Jëker du banc villageois de Diamegueune est créé le  07 décembre 2010. il es composé de  21 femmes issues du même quartier et qui s'activent dans le petit commerce.
Madame Bator la responsable est âgée de 47 ans, mariée mère de 05 enfants. Elle fait du commerce et de l'aviculture. Sur la photo elle est debout à droite couverte d'un châle blanc.
Après chaque financement elle achéte des poussins qu'elle revend 04 mois après pour préparer son remboursement.
Son prêt lui permettra d'acheter des poussins à élever.  
Elle aide son mari dans les besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
The solidarity group Sop Sa Jëker of the Banc Villageois of Diamegueune was created on December 7, 2010. It is composed of 21 women who are from the same district and who are active in small-scale commerce. 

Ms. Bator, the group's official, is 47 years old, married, and the mother of five children. She works in commerce and raises poultry. In the photo, she is the one standing at the right and wrapped in a white shawl. With every loan, she purchases chicks that she sells four months later in order to make her payment. Her loan will enable her to buy some chicks to raise. She helps out her husband with family needs.

loans.use: to do commerce and raise poultry

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
This is Natividad, 48, resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Fidel, and the mother to their two children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Natividad operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Natividad  makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and by selling them individually. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. Natividad earns a minimum of Php 1500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php 11,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Natividad hopes to be able to expand soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and the fellowship group is also a place where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God through her studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Kawral Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Kawral a été créé le 31 décembre 2011.Il est composé de 10 femmes qui sont issues du même village. Leur principale activité est le petit commerce.

Madame Adama est responsable du groupe,elle est âgée de 36 ans, est mariée et mère de 04 enfants.Sa principale activité est le commerce du sucre,du thé et de l'arachide.

Elle dispose d'une bonne expérience de cette activité pour l'avoir pratiqué plusieurs années. 

Son prêt lui permettra de s'approvisionner en quantité suffisante et d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaires.

Son objectif est de faire de l'embauche bovine,ce qui lui permettra d'augmenter sa capacité d'épargne.
texts.en:
The solidarity group Kawral was created on December 31, 2011. It is composed of ten women who are from the same village. Their main work involves small-scale commerce. 

Ms. Adama is the group's official. She is 36 years old, married, and the mother of four children. Her main business is commerce in sugar, tea, and peanuts. She has good experience in this business because she has worked at it for several years. Her loan will enable her to stock up on a sufficient quantity (of goods) and to increase her turnover. Her goal is to fatten cattle, which will allow her to increase her ability to save money.

loans.use: to buy, sugar, tea, and peanuts

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more seeds and manure for his banana plantation.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is a 45 year old Rwandan entrepreneur. He is married and has five children between the ages of six and 17. His wife is a farmer and all of their children go to school. Since 2006, Emmanuel has been successfully running a general store. He has made improvements to his store since he opened it and it is now a thriving business that helps support his family. With this loan, Emmanuel will purchase sugar, rice, beans, cooking oil, and tomatoes to sell in his store, which will sustain his business. Emmanuel plans to save the profits from his business so he can reinvest and provide for his family in the future.

loans.use: to buy items such as sugar, rice, beans, etc. for his general store.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
This is Elvie, 52, a resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Benjamin, and mother to their two children. With her husband, Elvie manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Elvie operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages, piecemeal, to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Elvie earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 700 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Elvie  hopes to be able to expand soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Jannette

texts.en:
Jeanette is a Rwandan entrepreneur. She is married and has 3 children between the ages of 4 and 9 years old. Her husband is a driver and all of her children are in school.

Jeanette runs a business selling breads, and her business has grown since she first started it. She also makes her own packaging materials. She uses the profits from her business to provide for her family.

She will used this loan to purchase more bread, cakes, and packaging materials that she will sell to meet the growing demands of her business.

loans.use: to buy bread, cakes and some packaging materials.

loans.name: Leolisa

texts.en:
Leliosa, 35, is a resident of GMA,Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Daniel, and mother of her five children. With her husband, Leliosa manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Leliosa operates a buy and sell business. She buys general merchandise from wholesalers and sells them piecemeal, with a little profit. Products can range from tools to household wares and other products. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options that are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP1500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP23, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Leolisa dreams to be able to give her all of her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for merchandise and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Elias

texts.en:
Elias is a 43 year old Rwandan entrepreneur who is married. He has 3 children between the ages of 3 and 7. His wife sells clothing and all of his children are in school, apart from the youngest.

Elias runs a business selling second hand clothes and bedsheets. He began selling as a wholesaler but now sells in a retail facility. He will use this loan to purchase additional clothes and bedsheets that he will sell to meet the demands of his business.

With the profits from his business, Elias plans to renovate his house and provide food for his family

loans.use: to purchase clothes and bed sheets to sell.

loans.name: Ani

texts.en:
Ani is a 24 year old lady who is married to Lody, a 25 year old man. They have three children, namely: Firdaus,  Risky,and the youngest one is Angelina. Both Firdaus and Risky are no longer at school. They dropped out from school because Ani and her husband could not afford to pay their school fee. 

Ani and her family live in a rented house. To support their family life, she and her husband run a kiosk business. They have been running the business for five years since moving. With the savings that Ani had, she initiated the business by purchasing limited stocks for the kiosk. Ani recognized that the income from the business is not enough, as they only have limited stock. This situation drove Ani and her husband to operate the business for 24 hours.

Ani is planning to add more inventory at her kiosk because she had spent the profit from her business to meet her maternity needs. She is requesting a loan of IDR 6,000,000 to buy plenty of kiosk items like sugar, rice, soft drinks, bread, etc., as demanded by the customers around her. She hopes that her loan application will be approved.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, soft drink, bread, etc., to sell.

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
This is Marissa, 41, a resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Angelito, and mother of two children: one is in high school and the oldest is already working. By the grace of God, Marissa has managed to support her children's schooling. With her husband, she manages the household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Marissa maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customers order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 3000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP35, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
